Apusis a faintconstellationin the southern sky, first defined in the late 16th century. Its name means "no feet" inGreek languageGreek, and it represents abird-of-paradise(which were once believed to lack feet). Itsgenitiveis "Apodis".
article.heading: History
article.paragraph: Apus was one of twelve constellations created byPetrus Planciusfrom the observations ofPieter Dirkszoon KeyserandFrederick de Houtman. It first appeared on a 35 cm diameter celestial globe published in 1597 or 1598 in Amsterdam by Plancius withJodocus Hondius.sfnRidpath200176-77cite webhttp://www.universetoday.com/19562/apus/ApusPlotnerTammyUniverse Today13 October 200822 April 2012Plancius called the constellationParadysvogel Apis Indica; the first word isDutch languageDutchfor "bird of paradise", of genusPteridophora, but the others areLatinfor "Indian Bee".Apis(Latin for "bee") is presumably an error foravis("bird").cite webhttp://www.ianridpath.com/startales/apus.htmApusRidpathIanStar Tales10 April 2012

The nameApusis derived from the Greekapous, meaning "without feet". This referred to the Western misconception that the bird-of-paradise had no feet, which arose because the only specimens available in the West had their feet and wings removed.Such specimens began to arrive in Europe in 1522, when the survivors ofFerdinand Magellan's expedition brought them home.sfnStaal1988252
After its introduction on Plancius's globe, the constellation's first known appearance in a celestial atlas was inJohann Bayer'sUranometriaof 1603, where it was called "Apis Indica".

Richard Allen reports Semler's assertion that de Houtman, who observed the southern constellations from the island of Sumatra, took his ideas for the formation of Apus (as well asPhoenix (constellation)PhoenixandIndus_(constellation)Indus) from the Chinese, who knew the stars of Apus as the "Little Wonder Bird",Richard H. Allen (1899) Star Names: Their Lore and Meaning, p. 45 <http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Gazetteer/Topics/astronomy/_Texts/secondary/ALLSTA/Apus*.html>and that Semler's assertion was disputed by Ideler (though Ideler acknowledged the Chinese constellations).
article.heading: Characteristics
article.paragraph: Covering 206.3 square degrees and hence 0.500% of the sky, Antlia ranks 67th of the88 modern constellationsby area.cite webhttp://www.ianridpath.com/constellations1.htmConstellations: Andromeda–IndusStar Tales[[Ian Ridpath|Ridpath, Ian]]self-published26 August 2015Its position in theSouthern Celestial Hemispheremeans that the wholeconstellationis visible to observers south of 7N.efnWhile parts of the constellation technically rise above the horizon to observers between the 7°N and 22°N, stars within a few degrees of the horizon are to all intents and purposes unobservable.<ref nameIt is bordered byAra (constellation)Ara,Triangulum AustraleandCircinusto the north,MuscaandChamaeleonto the west,Octansto the south, andPavo (constellation)Pavoto the east. The three-letter abbreviation for the constellation, as adopted by theInternational Astronomical Unionin 1922, is 'Aps'.cite journalRussellHenry NorrisHenry Norris RussellThe New International Symbols for the Constellations[[Popular Astronomy (US magazine)|Popular Astronomy]]304691922PA.....30..469R1922The official constellation boundaries, as set byEugne Joseph DelporteEugne Delportein 1930, are defined by a polygon of six segments (illustrated in infobox). In theequatorial coordinate system, theright ascensioncoordinates of these borders lie betweenRA1349.5andRA1827.3, while thedeclinationcoordinates are between -67.48 and -83.12.Cite journalApus, Constellation BoundaryThe ConstellationsInternational Astronomical Unionhttp://www.iau.org/public/constellations/#aps26 August 2015
article.heading: Notable features
article.paragraph: Image:Constellation Apus.jpgthumbleft200pxThe constellation Apus as it can be seen by the naked eye.The most prominent deep-sky objects in Apus include the globular clustersNGC 6101and IC 4499 as well as the spiral galaxy IC 4633.
article.heading: Stars
article.paragraph: Within the constellation's borders, there are 39 stars brighter than or equal toapparent magnitude 6.5.efnObjects of magnitude 6.5 are among the faintest visible to the unaided eye in suburban-rural transition night skies.{{cite web|url
